Hi Cedric,

I agree with you. A scripting language would be the most flexib=
le way to
support every kind of "rule". Inventing an own language would def=
initely
make NO sense.

From a JUnit perspective, there should be some argu=
ments in mind:

- JUnit tends to avoid references to external libraries
- A=
ny additional jars to be used for running tests will confuse people
(which =
jars has to be included ?)
- Any 3rdParty library would increase distributi=
on volume. OK, BeanShell
core is about 120k (compared to JUnit 4 with about=
 600k) , no really
convincing argument ;-)

The use cases I had in past are=
 almost based on:
- standard rules like "server available", "DB available",=
 "DB filled with
test data", ...
- existence of any files and or configurat=
ions

Either this "rules" are shared, common code in some helper classes, o=
r are
dependent on current test setup (e.g. DB connection), where I impleme=
nt this
rule in context of current test case (reusing existing code).

Usin=
g script only code will result in more distributed logic, which may be
more=
 difficult to maintain. And some predefined rules like date checks,
platfor=
m configuration will even support widely used rules with a very easy
to und=
erstand syntax,

Jochen

  A more flexible way to =
address this is to use a scripting language.

  TestNG allows you to define=
 such clauses in BeanShell, so that, for
example,
  if you want certain tes=
ts to run on weekends only, you would use the
  following code:

  <test na=
me=3D"Basic" >
  <script language=3D"beanshell"><![CDATA[
  int today =3D C=
alendar.getInstance().
  get(Calendar.DAY_OF_WEEK);
  return today =3D=3D C=
alendar.SATURDAY ||
  today =3D=3D Calendar.SUNDAY;
  ]]></script>

  You c=
an also do more fun stuff, like asking the user if they wish to run
  each =
test method with a Swing dialog (more details
  here<http://beust.com/weblo=
g/archives/000325.html>
  ).

  BeanShell is very cool and very simple to i=
ntegrate in your applications,
I
  strongly recommend using it instead of r=
einventing your own expression
  language.

  Cedric
